page.title: 11FARMING IN LITTONDALE
page.content: Most farming in the Dale is hill farming. All the farmers have sheep, but some have cattle which they raise for beef, or as heifer rearing for dairy farmers elsewhere. In Littondale only three farms supply milk. Each farm has parcels of land in different places, so that each has meadow, pasture and rough grazing. Only one of the farms is ring-fenced. Swaldale and Dalesbred sheep are the typical breeds here. Some are crossed with Leicester and Masham tups. The tups are put to the ewes in late October or November. Lambing takes place from late March until May. The sheep are clipped in late June, and the main dipping takes place in October. Silage making starts in late June, and hay-making in July. Because of the long winter, cattle are kept inside from mid-November till May.
